column2: SHADD'S MUSICALE

column2: Henriette was visibly angry the other morning when I took to her the early mail and she discovered that Mrs. Van Varick Shadd had got ahead of her in the matter of Jockobinski, the monkey virtuoso.
column3: Henriette was visibly angry the other morning when I took to her the early mail and she discovered that mrs Van Varick Shadd had got ahead of her in the matter of Jockobinski, the monkey virtuoso.

column2: Society had been very much interested in the reported arrival in America of this wonderfully talented simian who could play the violin as well as Ysaye, and who as a performer on the piano was vastly the superior of Paderewski, because, taken in his infancy and specially trained for the purpose, he could play with his feet and tail as well as with his hands. It had been reported by Tommy Dare, the leading Newport authority on monkeys, that he had heard him play Brahm's "Variations on Paganini" with his paws on a piano, "Hiawatha" on a xylophone with his feet, and "Home, Sweet Home" with his tail on a harp simultaneously, in Paris a year ago, and that alongside of Jockobinski all other musical prodigies of the age became mere strummers.
column3: Society had been very much interested in the reported arrival in America of this wonderfully talented simian who could play the violin as well as y s a y e, and who as a performer on the piano was vastly the superior of Paderewski, because, taken in his infancy and specially trained for the purpose, he could play with his feet and tail as well as with his hands. It had been reported by Tommy Dare, the leading Newport authority on monkeys, that he had heard him play Brahm's "Variations on Paganini" with his paws on a piano, "Hiawatha" on a xylophone with his feet, and "Home, Sweet Home" with his tail on a harp simultaneously, in Paris a year ago, and that alongside of Jockobinski all other musical prodigies of the age became mere strummers.

column2: He's a whole orchestra in himself, said Tommy enthusiastically, "and is the only living creature that I know of who can tackle a whole symphony without the aid of a hired man."
column3: He's a whole orchestra in himself, said Tommy enthusiastically, "and is the only living creature that I know of who can tackle a whole symphony without the aid of a hired man."

column2: Of course society was on the _qui vive_ for a genius of so riotous an order as this, and all the wealthy families of Newport vied with one another for the privilege of being first to welcome him to our shores, not because he was a freak, mind you, but "for art's sweet sake." Mrs. Gushington-Andrews offered twenty-five hundred dollars for him as a week-end guest, and Mrs. Gaster immediately went her bid a hundred per cent.
column3: Of course society was on the underscore qui vive underscore for a genius of so riotous an order as this, and all the wealthy families of Newport vied with one another for the privilege of being first to welcome him to our shores, not because he was a freak, mind you, but "for art's sweet sake." mrs Gushington Andrews offered twenty five hundred dollars for him as a week end guest, and mrs Gaster immediately went her bid a hundred per cent.

column2: better.
column3: better.

column2: Henriette, in order to outdo every one else, promptly put in a bid of ten thousand dollars for a single evening, and had supposed the bargain closed when along came Mrs. Shadd's cards announcing that she would be pleased to have Mrs. Van Raffles at Onyx House on Friday evening, August 27th, to meet Herr Jockobinski, the eminent virtuoso.
column3: Henriette, in order to outdo every one else, promptly put in a bid of ten thousand dollars for a single evening, and had supposed the bargain closed when along came mrs Shadd's cards announcing that she would be pleased to have mrs Van Raffles at Onyx House on Friday evening, august twenty seventh, to meet Herr Jockobinski, the eminent virtuoso.

column2: It's very annoying, said Henriette, as she opened and read the invitation.
column3: It's very annoying, said Henriette, as she opened and read the invitation.

column2: I had quite set my heart on having Jockobinski here.	I had quite set my heart on having Jockobinski here.
column3: true

column2: Not that I care particularly about the music end of it, but because there is nothing that gives a woman so assured a social position as being the hostess of an animal of his particular kind.
column3: Not that I care particularly about the music end of it, but because there is nothing that gives a woman so assured a social position as being the hostess of an animal of his particular kind.

column2: You remember, Bunny, how completely Mrs. Shadd wrested the leadership from Mrs. Gaster two seasons ago with her orang outang dinner, don't you?"
column3: You remember, Bunny, how completely mrs Shadd wrested the leadership from mrs Gaster two seasons ago with her orang outang dinner, don't you?"

column2: I confessed to having read something about such an incident in high society.
column3: I confessed to having read something about such an incident in high society.

column2: Well, said Henriette, "_this_ would have thrown that little episode wholly in the shade.
column3: Well, said Henriette, "underscore this underscore would have thrown that little episode wholly in the shade.

column2: Of course Mrs. Shadd is doing this to retain her grip, but it irritates me more than I can say to have her get it just the same.
column3: Of course mrs Shadd is doing this to retain her grip, but it irritates me more than I can say to have her get it just the same.

column2: Heaven knows I was willing to pay for it if I had to abscond with a national bank to get the money."
column3: Heaven knows I was willing to pay for it if I had to abscond with a national bank to get the money."

column2: It isn't too late, is it? I queried.
column3: It isn't too late, is it? I queried.

column2: Not too late? echoed Henriette.
column3: Not too late? echoed Henriette.

column2: Not too late with Mrs. Shadd's cards out and the whole thing published in the papers?
column3: Not too late with mrs Shadd's cards out and the whole thing published in the papers?

column2: It's never too late for a woman of your resources to do anything she has a mind to do, said I. "It seems to me that a person who could swipe a Carnegie library the way you did should have little difficulty in lifting a musicale.
column3: It's never too late for a woman of your resources to do anything she has a mind to do, said i "It seems to me that a person who could swipe a Carnegie library the way you did should have little difficulty in lifting a musicale.

column2: Of course I don't know how you could do it, but with _your_ mind--well, I should be surprised and disappointed if you couldn't devise some plan to accomplish your desires."
column3: Of course I don't know how you could do it, but with underscore your underscore mind-well, I should be surprised and disappointed if you couldn't devise some plan to accomplish your desires."

column2: Henriette was silent for a moment, and then her face lit up with one of her most charming smiles.
column3: Henriette was silent for a moment, and then her face lit up with one of her most charming smiles.

column2: Bunny, do you know that at times, in spite of your supreme stupidity, you are a source of positive inspiration to me? she said, looking at me, fondly, I ventured to think.
column3: Bunny, do you know that at times, in spite of your supreme stupidity, you are a source of positive inspiration to me? she said, looking at me, fondly, I ventured to think.

column2: I am glad if it is so, said I. "Sometimes, dear Henriette, you will find the most beautiful flowers growing out of the blackest mud.
column3: I am glad if it is so, said i "Sometimes, dear Henriette, you will find the most beautiful flowers growing out of the blackest mud.

column2: Perhaps hid in the dull residuum of my poor but honest gray matter lies the seed of real genius that will sprout the loveliest blossoms of achievement."
column3: Perhaps hid in the dull residuum of my poor but honest gray matter lies the seed of real genius that will sprout the loveliest blossoms of achievement."

column2: Well, anyhow, dear, you have started me thinking, and maybe we'll have Jockobinski at Bolivar Lodge yet, she murmured.
column3: Well, anyhow, dear, you have started me thinking, and maybe we'll have Jockobinski at Bolivar Lodge yet, she murmured.

column2: I want to have him first, of course, or not at all.	I want to have him first, of course, or not at all.

column2: To be second in doing a thing of that kind is worse than never doing it at all."
column3: To be second in doing a thing of that kind is worse than never doing it at all."

column2: Days went by and not another word was spoken on the subject of Jockobinski and the musicale, and I began to feel that at last Henriette had reached the end of her ingenuity--though for my own part I could not blame her if she failed to find some plausible way out of her disappointment.
column3: Days went by and not another word was spoken on the subject of Jockobinski and the musicale, and I began to feel that at last Henriette had reached the end of her ingenuity-though for my own part one could not blame her if she failed to find some plausible way out of her disappointment.

column2: Wednesday night came, and, consumed by curiosity to learn just how the matter stood, I attempted to sound Henriette on the subject.
column3: Wednesday night came, and, consumed by curiosity to learn just how the matter stood, I attempted to sound Henriette on the subject.

column2: I should like Friday evening off, Mrs. Van Raffles, said I. "If you are going to Mrs. Shadd's musicale you will have no use for me."
column3: I should like Friday evening off, mrs Van Raffles, said i "If you are going to mrs Shadd's musicale you will have no use for me."

column2: Shut up, Bunny, she returned, abruptly.
column3: Shut up, Bunny, she returned, abruptly.

column2: I shall need you Friday night more than ever before.	I shall need you Friday night more than ever before.
column3: true

column2: Just take this note over to Mrs. Shadd this evening and leave it--mind you, don't wait for an answer but just leave it, that's all."
column3: Just take this note over to mrs Shadd this evening and leave it-mind you, don't wait for an answer but just leave it, that's all."

column2: She arose from the table and handed me a daintily scented missive addressed to Mrs. Shadd, and I faithfully executed her errand.
column3: She arose from the table and handed me a daintily scented missive addressed to mrs Shadd, and I faithfully executed her errand.

column2: Bunderby, the Shadd's butler, endeavored to persuade me to wait for an answer, but assuring him that I wasn't aware that an answer was expected I returned to Bolivar Lodge.
column3: Bunderby, the Shadd's butler, endeavored to persuade me to wait for an answer, but assuring him that I wasn't aware that an answer was expected I returned to Bolivar Lodge.

column2: An hour later Bunderby appeared at the back door and handed me a note addressed to my mistress, which I immediately delivered.
column3: An hour later Bunderby appeared at the back door and handed me a note addressed to my mistress, which I immediately delivered.

column2: Is Bunderby waiting? asked Henriette as she read the note.
column3: Is Bunderby waiting? asked Henriette as she read the note.

column3: Yes, I answered.

column2: Tell him to hand this to Mrs. Shadd the very first thing upon her return to-morrow evening, she said, hastily scribbling off a note and putting it in an envelope, which by chance she left unsealed, so that on my way back below-stairs I was able to read it.
column3: Tell him to hand this to mrs Shadd the very first thing upon her return to morrow evening, she said, hastily scribbling off a note and putting it in an envelope, which by chance she left unsealed, so that on my way back below stairs I was able to read it.

column2: What it said was that she would be only too happy to oblige Mrs. Shadd, and was very sorry indeed to hear that her son had been injured in an automobile accident while running into Boston from Bar Harbor.
column3: What it said was that she would be only too happy to oblige mrs Shadd, and was very sorry indeed to hear that her son had been injured in an automobile accident while running into Boston from Bar Harbor.

column2: It closed with the line, "you must know, my dear Pauline, that there isn't anything I wouldn't do for you, come weal or come woe."
column3: It closed with the line, "you must know, my dear Pauline, that there isn't anything I wouldn't do for you, come weal or come woe."

column2: This I handed to Bunderby and he made off.
column3: This I handed to Bunderby and he made off.

column2: On my return Henriette was dressed for travel.
column3: On my return Henriette was dressed for travel.

column2: I must take the first train for New York, she said, excitedly.
column3: I must take the first train for New York, she said, excitedly.

column2: I am going myself to make all the necessary arrangements at the New York end.
column3: I am going myself to make all the necessary arrangements at the New York end.

column2: All you have to do is to get things ready and rely on your ignorance for everything else.
column3: All you have to do is to get things ready and rely on your ignorance for everything else.

column2: I could only reflect that if a successful issue were dependent upon my ignorance I had a plentiful supply of it to fall back on.

column2: Henriette made off at once for Providence by motor-car, and got the midnight train out of Boston for the city where, from what I learned afterwards, she must have put in a strenuous day on Thursday.
column3: Henriette made off at once for Providence by motor car, and got the midnight train out of Boston for the city where, from what I learned afterwards, she must have put in a strenuous day on Thursday.

column2: At any rate, a great sensation was sprung on Newport on Friday morning.
column3: At any rate, a great sensation was sprung on Newport on Friday morning.

column2: Every member of the smart set in the ten-o'clock mail received a little engraved card stating that owing to sudden illness in the Shadd family the Shadd musicale for that evening would be held at Bolivar Lodge instead of in the Onyx House ballroom.
column3: Every member of the smart set in the ten o'clock mail received a little engraved card stating that owing to sudden illness in the Shadd family the Shadd musicale for that evening would be held at Bolivar Lodge instead of in the Onyx House ballroom.

column2: Friday afternoon Jockobinski's private and particular piano arrived at the Lodge and was set up promptly in the music-room, and later when the caterers arrived with the supper for the four hundred odd guests bidden to the feast all was in readiness for them.
column3: Friday afternoon Jockobinski's private and particular piano arrived at the Lodge and was set up promptly in the music room, and later when the caterers arrived with the supper for the four hundred odd guests bidden to the feast all was in readiness for them.

column2: Everything was running smoothly, and, although Henriette had not yet arrived, I felt easy and secure of mind until nearing five-thirty o'clock when Mrs. Shadd herself drove up to the front-door.
column3: Everything was running smoothly, and, although Henriette had not yet arrived, I felt easy and secure of mind until nearing five thirty o'clock when mrs Shadd herself drove up to the front door.

column2: You've guessed right, said Henriette.
column3: You've guessed right, said Henriette.

column2: As a postscript let me say that until he reads this I don't believe Tommy Dare ever guessed what a successful joke he perpetrated upon Mrs. Shadd and the fair Henriette.
column3: As a postscript let me say that until he reads this I don't believe Tommy Dare ever guessed what a successful joke he perpetrated upon mrs Shadd and the fair Henriette.

column2: Even then I doubt if he realizes what a good one it was on--everybody.
column3: Even then I doubt if he realizes what a good one it was on-everybody.

column2: XI
column3: XI

column2: THE ADVENTURE OF MRS.
column3: THE ADVENTURE OF mrs

column2: INNITT'S COOK
column3: INNITT'S COOK

column2: It is curious, Bunny, said Henriette the other morning after an unusually late breakfast, "to observe by what qualities certain of these Newport families have arrived, as the saying is.
column3: It is curious, Bunny, said Henriette the other morning after an unusually late breakfast, "to observe by what qualities certain of these Newport families have arrived, as the saying is.

column2: The Gasters of course belong at the top by patent right.
column3: The Gasters of course belong at the top by patent right.

column2: Having invented American society, or at least the machine that at present controls it, they are entitled to all the royalties it brings in.
column3: Having invented American society, or at least the machine that at present controls it, they are entitled to all the royalties it brings in.

column2: The Rockerbilts got there all of a sudden by the sheer lavishness of their entertainment and their ability to give bonds to keep it up.
column3: The Rockerbilts got there all of a sudden by the sheer lavishness of their entertainment and their ability to give bonds to keep it up.

column2: The Van Varick Shadds flowed in through their unquestioned affiliation with the ever-popular Delaware Shadds and the Roe-Shadds of the Hudson, two of the oldest and most respected families of the United States, reinforced by the Napoleonic qualities of the present Mrs. Shadd in the doing of unexpected things.
column3: The Van Varick Shadds flowed in through their unquestioned affiliation with the ever popular Delaware Shadds and the Roe Shadds of the Hudson, two of the oldest and most respected families of the United States, reinforced by the Napoleonic qualities of the present mrs Shadd in the doing of unexpected things.

column2: The Gullets, thanks to the fact that Mrs. Gullet is the acknowledged mother-in-law of three British dukes, two Italian counts, and a French marquis, are safely anchored in the social haven where they would be, and the rumor that Mrs. Gushington-Andrews has written a book that is a trifle risque fixes her firmly in the social constellation--but the Innitts with only eighty thousand dollars per annum, the Dedbroke-Hickses with nothing a year, the Oliver-Sloshingtons with an income of judgments, the study of their arrival is mighty interesting."
column3: The Gullets, thanks to the fact that mrs Gullet is the acknowledged mother in law of three British dukes, two Italian counts, and a French marquis, are safely anchored in the social haven where they would be, and the rumor that mrs Gushington Andrews has written a book that is a trifle risque fixes her firmly in the social constellation-but the Innitts with only eighty thousand dollars per annum, the Dedbroke Hickses with nothing a year, the Oliver Sloshingtons with an income of judgments, the study of their arrival is mighty interesting."
